This award strives to conserve biodiversity and manage natural resources in ways that maintain their long-term viability and preserve their potential to meet the needs of present and future generations. Activities include combating illegal and corrupt exploitation of natural resources and the control of invasive species. This includes Lake Tanganyika is located in northern Zambia and is the second largest freshwater lake in the world. It is home to an immense amount of biodiversity including hundreds of cichlid species. Many of the cichlid species are in high demand for the worldwide aquarium trade. In the first quarter of 2018, half of all illegal incidents in Nsumbu National Park (one of only three protected areas around Lake Tanganyika) were aquatic in nature. To address the illegal harvesting of protected cichlid species in Nsumbu National Park, this one-year grant will support: recruitment and training of rangers at Chunga Wildlife College, a requirement for rangers in Zambia; boat operation and aquatic training for existing rangers, including how to identify species and trade routes of cichlids to better direct law enforcement operations; workshops with relevant national wildlife and fisheries authorities on methods of live fish collection, international export routes, and value of fish exports; provision of fuel, rations, and boat engine maintenance to ensure continuity of aquatic patrols of Lake Tanganyika; and integration of the aquatic patrols into the wider law enforcement strategy for Nsumbu National Park to ensure intelligence and investigations are streamlined.. description.narrative: Despite its status as a lower-middle income country with mineral wealth, Zambia ranks poorly on human development indicators with child malnutrition and its rural poverty levels among the highest in the world. U.S. assistance to Zambia seeks to reduce poverty through the promotion of agriculture-led economic development and food security; combat deforestation and wildlife poaching; expand and improves the quality of health and education opportunities; fight HIV/AIDS, tuberculosis, and malaria; work to decrease maternal and child mortality; strengthen democratic and accountable governance; and build Zambian capacity to promote regional peace, security, and stability.
